prefix: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem.
problem_prompt: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem. Find the residue of $182\cdot 12 - 15\cdot 7 + 3\pmod{14}$.
solution:
Since $182$ is divisible by 14, the first term does not affect the residue of the whole expression, modulo 14. Since $15\cdot 7$ is divisible by 7 but not by 14 (since it isn't even), it has a residue of 7. So the residue of the sum is  $$
182\cdot 12 - 15\cdot 7 + 3 \equiv 0 - 7 + 3 \equiv -4 \equiv \boxed{10} \pmod{14}.
$$
gpt_response:
To find the residue of the expression $182\cdot 12 - 15\cdot 7 + 3\pmod{14}$, we first evaluate the expression modulo $14$:

$182\cdot 12 \equiv 0 \pmod{14}$ (since $182 = 13\cdot 14$)

Similarly, $15\cdot 7 \equiv 1\cdot 7 \equiv 7\pmod{14}$

Therefore, the expression becomes:

$0 - 7 + 3 \equiv -4 \equiv 10\pmod{14}$

So, the residue of $182\cdot 12 - 15\cdot 7 + 3\pmod{14}$ is $\boxed{10}$.
solution_prompt:

$182\cdot 12 \equiv 0 \pmod{14}$ (since $182 = 13\cdot 14$)

Similarly, $15\cdot 7 \equiv 1\cdot 7 \equiv 7\pmod{14}$

Therefore, the expression becomes:

$0 - 7 + 3 \equiv -4 \equiv 10\pmod{14}$

So, the residue of $182\cdot 12 - 15\cdot 7 + 3\pmod{14}$ is $\boxed{10}$.
